P001.name: James Wilson
P001.chief_complaint: Persistent cough with fever for 5 days, worsening shortness of breath

clinical_notes.author: Dr. Park
clinical_notes.content: 58M presents with 5-day history of productive cough with yellow-green sputum, fever (self-measured 38.5C at home), and progressive dyspnea. No hemoptysis. Reports decreased appetite and malaise. PMH significant for T2DM, HTN, hyperlipidemia. Chest auscultation reveals crackles in right lower lobe. Decreased breath sounds on right base. CXR pending.

P001.family_history: Father: MI at age 62. Mother: T2DM, alive. Brother: hypertension.
P001.social_history: Former smoker (20 pack-years, quit 5 years ago). Occasional alcohol use. Retired office worker. Lives with wife.

P002.name: Sarah Kim
P002.chief_complaint: Severe headache with neck stiffness and photophobia for 2 days

clinical_notes.author: Dr. Martinez
clinical_notes.content: 32F presents with severe headache (8/10) that started 2 days ago with progressive neck stiffness and photophobia. Reports fever at home. Denies recent travel or sick contacts. No history of immunosuppression. Kernig and Brudzinski signs positive on exam. This presentation is different from her usual migraines - more acute onset, higher fever, and nuchal rigidity.

P002.social_history: Non-smoker. Social drinker. Software engineer. No recent travel.

P003.name: Robert Chen
P003.chief_complaint: Acute right lower quadrant abdominal pain with nausea and vomiting

clinical_notes.author: Dr. Williams
clinical_notes.content: 45M presents with acute onset RLQ abdominal pain started 12 hours ago, initially periumbilical then migrated to RLQ. Associated nausea and 2 episodes of vomiting. Low-grade fever. McBurney's point tenderness positive. Rebound tenderness and guarding present. Psoas sign positive. Rovsing sign positive.

P003.family_history: Father: colon cancer at age 65. Mother: alive and well.

drug_interactions.description: Fluoroquinolones may alter blood glucose levels when used with metformin. May cause hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia.
drug_interactions.recommendation: Monitor blood glucose closely. Adjust metformin dosage if necessary.

drug_interactions.description: ACE inhibitors increase potassium retention. Concurrent potassium supplementation may lead to hyperkalemia.
drug_interactions.recommendation: Avoid concurrent use or monitor potassium levels very closely.

drug_interactions.description: Macrolide antibiotics may increase the anticoagulant effect of warfarin, increasing bleeding risk.
drug_interactions.recommendation: Monitor INR closely. May need warfarin dose adjustment.

drug_interactions.description: Clarithromycin inhibits CYP3A4, significantly increasing statin levels and risk of rhabdomyolysis.
drug_interactions.recommendation: Avoid combination. Use azithromycin as alternative macrolide.

drug_interactions.description: Rifampin is a potent CYP3A4 inducer that significantly reduces oral contraceptive efficacy.
drug_interactions.recommendation: Use alternative contraception method during and 28 days after rifampin therapy.

drug_interactions.description: Risk of lactic acidosis. Metformin should be held before and 48h after iodinated contrast.
drug_interactions.recommendation: Hold metformin 48 hours before and after contrast administration. Check renal function.

GL001.title: ATS/IDSA Guidelines for Management of Community-Acquired Pneumonia
GL001.source: American Thoracic Society / Infectious Diseases Society of America
GL001.summary: Evidence-based recommendations for the diagnosis and treatment of community-acquired pneumonia in adults.
recommendations: For outpatient treatment without comorbidities: amoxicillin or doxycycline
For outpatient with comorbidities: respiratory fluoroquinolone OR beta-lactam + macrolide
For inpatient non-ICU: respiratory fluoroquinolone OR beta-lactam + macrolide
For inpatient ICU: beta-lactam + macrolide OR beta-lactam + respiratory fluoroquinolone
Obtain blood cultures and sputum culture before initiating antibiotics in hospitalized patients
Start antibiotics within 4 hours of admission
Consider local antibiogram for empiric therapy

GL002.title: IDSA Guidelines for Bacterial Meningitis Management
GL002.summary: Clinical practice guidelines for the management of bacterial meningitis.
recommendations: Perform lumbar puncture urgently if meningitis is suspected (unless contraindicated)
Start empiric antibiotics immediately - do not delay for imaging
Empiric therapy for adults: vancomycin + third-generation cephalosporin (ceftriaxone or cefotaxime)
Add dexamethasone 0.15 mg/kg IV q6h for 4 days, started before or with first antibiotic dose
Blood cultures before antibiotics
CT scan before LP only if: immunocompromised, history of CNS disease, new-onset seizure, papilledema, altered consciousness, focal neurologic deficit
Adjust antibiotics based on CSF culture and sensitivity results

GL003.title: SAGES Guidelines for Diagnosis and Treatment of Acute Appendicitis
GL003.source: Society of American Gastrointestinal and Endoscopic Surgeons
GL003.summary: Guidelines for the clinical diagnosis and surgical management of acute appendicitis.
recommendations: CT abdomen/pelvis is the imaging modality of choice (sensitivity >95%)
Ultrasound as first-line imaging in pediatric patients and pregnant women
Alvarado score â‰¥7 strongly suggests appendicitis
Laparoscopic appendectomy is the standard of care for uncomplicated appendicitis
Antibiotic-first approach may be considered for uncomplicated appendicitis in select patients
Preoperative antibiotics: single dose of broad-spectrum antibiotic
NPO status and IV fluid resuscitation before surgery
Pain management: avoid NSAIDs if GI bleeding risk; use acetaminophen or opioids
